Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing MIDCAB and Conventional CABG for Myocardial Revascularization

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation and blinding were not applicable due to the study's retrospective nature.

Participants.evidence: This retrospective analysis included 1915 patients with coronary artery disease who underwent either MIDCAB or conventional CABG at Tel-Aviv Medical Center from January 2000 to December 2011.

Intervention.evidence: This study aimed to compare the early and late outcomes of minimally invasive direct coronary artery bypass (MIDCAB) versus conventional coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the early and late outcomes of minimally invasive direct coronary artery bypass (MIDCAB) versus conventional coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was overall survival, measured over a median follow-up of 20 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and blinding were not applicable due to the study's retrospective nature.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation and blinding were not applicable due to the study's retrospective nature.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This retrospective analysis included 1915 patients with coronary artery disease who underwent either MIDCAB or conventional CABG at Tel-Aviv Medical Center from January 2000 to December 2011.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 1915 patients, 1752 underwent conventional CABG and 163 underwent MIDCAB.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Early mortality was lower in the MIDCAB group (0.6% vs. 3.6%, p = 0.042). Long-term survival rates at 10, 15, and 20 years were higher in the MIDCAB group: 76.7% vs. 55.1%, 63.7% vs. 37.1%, and 53.4% vs. 23.1%, respectively (p < 0.001).

Funding.evidence: No specific funding was received for this study.
